The Rhinoceros Horn
â€œHaving laid aside the rod with regard to all beings,
Not harming any of them,
One should not wish for a child, let alone a companion.
One should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€
â€œFor one who has made connections, there are attachments;
From attachment, this suffering arises.
Seeing the danger that comes from attachment,
One should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€

â€œJust as a tree with spreading branches is shaken by the wind,
So is one with attachments to children and wives.
Like a tree trunk, unattached,
One should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€
â€œJust as an animal is free in the wilderness,
Going wherever it wants to graze,
A wise person, seeing the danger in being led around,
Should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€
â€œIn the midst of companions, there is calling out,
In dwelling, in standing, in going, and in wandering.
Looking on with equanimity at what is not coveted or sought after,
One should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€
â€œIn the midst of friends there is the delight of play,

Disgusted with the separation from the dear one,
One should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€
â€œOne should be without hostility in the four directions,
Being content with whatever comes along.
Not trembling at the occurrence of calamities,
One should wander alone like the horn of a rhinoceros.â€
â€œSome who have gone forth are difficult to support,

â€œHaving cast off the marks of a householder,

â€œIf one finds a wise friend, a companion,
A wise one who lives well together,
Having overcome all calamities,
One should go with him, pleased, mindful.â€
